title: Teapot
credit_line: Gift of Susan Pickens in memory of Mary Robb Ballantyne.
provenance_text:
This teapot belonged to five generations of the Robb family born and raised on the Robb Farm, one mile north of McDonald, PA, in Washington County.

Ebenezer Robb (b. 1810), wife: Eliza Wallace
Joseph Wallace Robb (b. 1851), wife: Rachel Lindsey
Mary Robb Douglass Smith, Laura Robb
Mary Robb Douglass Ballantyne (1927 - 1990)
Susan Robb Ballantyne Pickens (b. 1954)
Katie Susan Pickens (b. 1981)



Mary Robb Ballantyne requested 1 week before her death on March 7, 1990 that this teapot be put in a museum.

title: Portrait of Charles I (1600-1649)
medium: watercolor on cut paper; tortoise shell mounted wood frame
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Harry Oatway [-1917?], London, England, until sometime before November 1917 [1]; Estate of Harry Oatway, by November 1917; (sold at American Art Association, New York, NY, November 7, 1917); purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, November 7, 1917; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] Oatway must have died prior to November of 1917, when his collection went up for auction at the American Art Association as the collection of the "late Mr. Harry Oatway."

Henry Symons [1871-1921], London, England; (American Art Association sale, New York, NY, March 18, 1915) [1]; purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, March 18, 1915; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] Lot 1367, illustrated.

title: Miniature Portrait of Sir Samuel Garth (1661-1719)
medium: oil on copper; silver gilt frame
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
C. W. Sotheby, by June 1865 [1]. Henry Symons [1871-1921], London, England; (sold at American Art Association, New York, NY, March 18, 1915) [2]; purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, March 18, 1915; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] Exhibited at the South Kensington Museum exhibition of portrait miniatures, where it is listed as being lent by Mr. C. W. Sotheby. It is listed as number 1197. [2] Lot 1391.

title: Miniature Portrait of Louis XVII (1785-1795)
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Downham collection. (Sold at Salter, Simpson, & Sons, Bury St. Edmond's, England). Purchased by Lady Darwin, August 28, 1917; Herbert Dupuy, Pittsburgh, PA [1]; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] DuPuy notes that this item was purchased "by Lady Darwin" from the Salter, Simpson & Sons sale on August 28, 1917. However, it is not clear in what capacity Lady Darwin was acting, i.e. as DuPuy's agent, or as a collector in her own right. This is likely Lady Florence Henrietta Darwin, also known as Florence Henrietta Fisher and Florence Henrietta Maitland.

title: Fan
medium: mother of pearl, gold and silver applique, paper mounts
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
(Clara Millard, Teddington, England, by January 26, 1916) [1]; purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, January 26, 1916; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] Clara Millard was a dealer in rare books and objects. She focused on procuring sought after books and objects "to order" and published extensive catalogues of her holdings, as well as issuing challenges in newspapers daring collectors to stump her ability to locate a rare item.

title: Fan
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Miss A. G. Larter or Miss B. M. Kendall, until November 16, 1915 [1]; (sold at American Art Association, New York, NY, November 16, 1915); purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, November 16, 1915; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] The sale of the "Misses A. G. Larter and B. M. Kendall" happened at the American Art Association gallery on November 16, 1915. It is unclear at this time if the sale was the sale of two separate individuals, or a joint estate, or another situation. Research is ongoing.

title: Tobacco Grater
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Edouard Chappey. (Possibly sold at Gallerie Georges Petit, Paris, France, May 27, 1907) [1]. (Sold at American Art Association, New York, NY, February 11, 1924); purchased by Herbert Dupuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, February 11, 1924; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] The May 27 to May 31, 1907 sale of Edouard Chappey at Georges Petit includes a number of tabacco graters, however, many are included as a lot, without individual descriptions. It is possible that this item was included in lots 1345 to 1353, which were described as "Sous ces numéros, quinze rapes à tabac en ivoire oi os, à décors variés, des XVII et XVIII siécles. Seront divisées." Herbert DuPuy records that this item came from Chappey as well.

NOTES: [1] The May 27 to May 31, 1907 sale of Edouard Chappey at Georges Petit includes a number of tabacco graters, however, many are included as a lot, without individual descriptions. It is possible that this item was included in lots 1345 to 1353, which were described as "Sous ces numéros, quinze rapes à tabac en ivoire oi os, à décors variés, des XVII et XVIII siécles. Seront divisées." Herbert DuPuy records that this item came from Chappey as well.

title: Tobacco Grater
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Mr. Lehne, Paris, France. Purchased by Mrs. George W. Steele, by December 25, 1924; Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, December 25, 1924 [1]; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] Herbert DuPuy records this item as having been "Purchased from Mr. Lehne, Paris, and presented by Mrs. George W. Steele on Christmas, 1924." It is unclear if Mrs. Steele gave this to DuPuy as a gift for Christmas, or if it was presented to him in a different context, perhaps with Mrs. Steele operating as an agent?

title: Tobacco Grater

NOTES: [1] Herbert DuPuy records that he purchased this item on May 16, from Leon Gruel, but did not specify a year. The documentation could be implying that it was purchased in May of the year the gift was made, 1927, but there is no evidence to support this.

title: Egg coddler with Lid
credit_line: Gift of Herbert DuPuy
provenance_text:
Commissioned by Nathaniel Hayden, Hartford, CT; gift to Sidney Hayden, his son, Hartford, CT; gift to Augusta Hayden [1817-], Charleston, SC [1]; Mrs. Izard? [2]; Lily L. Harby, Charleston, SC; purchased by Herbert DuPuy [1856-1930], Pittsburgh, PA, March 3, 1916; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1927. 
NOTES: [1] According to Herbert DuPuy, Augusta Hayden's daughter buried this item on the grounds of the Villa Margherita in Charleston, SC to protect it during the Civil War. It was reportedly damaged by shell fire and repaired. [2] The notes indicate that this person's birth name was Otis, which means that this was one of the female children of Nina Augusta Hayden, daughter of Augusta Haden. Nina Augusta married Arthur P. Otis of Charleston, SC on November 26, 1874.They had 5 daughters: Amy, Nina Hayden, Lottie, Maria Wwelsman and Eulia. Family geneaology records do not indicate which daughter became Mrs. Izard, and therefore the daughter-in-law of Judge Izard of Charleston, as noted in the documentation. See "Records of the Connecticut line of the Hayden family" by Jabez Haskell Hayden and William Benjamin Hayden.

title: Shepherd Boy with Recorder
credit_line: J. Willis Dalzell Memorial Collection, bequest of Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell
provenance_text:
Sir Thomas Baring [1772-1848] until 1843; sold to William Coningham in 1843; William Coningham, 1843 until June 9, 1849; sale, Christie and Manson, London, England, June 9, 1849, no. 21; purchased by Thomas Baring, M. P. [1799-1873] [1]; bequest to  his nephew, Thomas George Baring, Lord Northbrook, subsequently 1st Earl of Northbrook [1826-1904], London and Stratton Park, Hampshire, England, 1873 until at least 1889 [2]. John Levy Galleries, New York, NY, by December 1920 [3]; sold to Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell (Mary Beer Dalzell) [1844-1929], Pittsburgh, PA [4]; Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell, Pittsburgh, PA, December 4, 1920 until February 13, 1929; Mary B. Dalzell estate, February 1929; bequest to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, February 1929 [5].

Notes:
[1]. As by Murillo. Purchased for £152, 5s. See copy of the annotated auction catalogue from the Getty Research Institute in curatorial file. 
[2]. The work, listed as by Murillo, is no. 231 in the 1889 catalogue of the Earl of Northbrook collection. It left the Northbrook collection at an unknown date.
[3]. John Levy Galleries stock # 17543. It is listed as a Murillo work.
[4]. Mrs. Dalzell purchased the painting for $12000.
[5]. The painting was collected from Mrs. Dalzell's residence on Ridge Avenue in Pittsburgh and brought to Carnegie Institute on February 19, 1929. It was accessioned on February 25, 1929.

title: The Gothic Bridge at Eudes, Tours
credit_line: Bequest of Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell
provenance_text:
Mrs. J. Willis Dalzell (Mary Beer Dalzell) [1844-1929], Pittsburgh, PA, until February 13, 1929; Mary B. Dalzell estate, February 1929; bequest to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, February 1929.

Notes:
The painting was collected from Mrs. Dalzell's residence on Ridge Avenue in Pittsburgh and brought to Carnegie Institute on February 19, 1929. It was accessioned on February 25, 1929.

title: St. John the Evangelist
credit_line: Estate of Daniel E. Clemson (?)
provenance_text:
Carl W. Hamilton [1886-1967], New York, NY; Daniel M. Clemson [1853-1936], Pittsburgh, PA, until 1936 [1]; Estate of Daniel E. Clemson; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, June 1937. 
NOTES: [1] Correspondence from the estate of Daniel M. Clemson on May 12, 1937 indicates that Clemson purchased this object from Carl W. Hamilton "approximately 15 years ago" which would mean Clemson acquired this object in approximately 1922.  However, an appraisal addressed to Carl W. Hamilton from Charles L Haskell dated February 12, 1931 indicates that Hamilton still owned the item in 1931. The beginning of Clemson's ownership is therefore uncertain.

title: The Beggar Boy
credit_line: Gift of Sarah Mellon Scaife and Richard King Mellon in memory of their mother, Jennie King Mellon
provenance_text:
Private Collection, Seville, Spain, before 1905; Sully & Co., London, England, until 1905; purchased by David Thompson Watson (1844-1916), Pittsburgh, PA, 1905 until February 24, 1916; D. T. Watson estate, February 1916 until April 17, 1917; D. T. Watson sale, American Art Association, Plaza Hotel, New York, NY, April 16-17, 1917, no. 154 [1]; Richard Beatty Mellon [1858-1933], Pittsburgh, PA, April 1917 until December 1, 1933; his wife, Jeannie King Mellon (d. November 1938); by descent to their daughter, Sarah Mellon Scaife [1903-1965], Pittsburgh, PA and their son, Richard King Mellon [1899-1970], Pittsburgh, PA [2]; their gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, December 1940.

Notes: 
[1]. " Highly Important Old and Modern Paintings of Sterling Artistic Distinction". This painting, titled "Boy with Fruit and Bread" and illustrated in the catalogue, sold on April 17, 1917 for $6000 to W. W. Seaman, agent, apparently, for R. B. Mellon. See American Art News, April 21, 1917, p. 9.
[2]. Mrs. Scaife and Mr. Mellon donated this and two other paintings in memory of their mother.

title: Platter
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. James H. Beal
provenance_text:
John Goodrich Henry, MD [1858-1941], Winchendon, MA, until January 18, 1941; his daughter Mrs. Ruth Hubbard, Keene, NH [1]; The Trade Shop, East Boothbay, ME, until August 1955 [2]; Mrs. James H. Beal (born Rebecca Huebley Jones) [1898-1993], Pittsburgh, PA, August 1955 until December 1955 [3]; gift to Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, December 1955 [4].

Notes:
[1]. The Henry family provenance, provided to Mrs. Beal by Mrs. E. Prentiss Jones (see note [2],) is recorded in Mrs. Beal's notes and correspondence on the subject (see donor file.) It is unclear whether the platter was purchased by The Trade Shop from Dr. Henry's daughter as owner or as representative of her father's estate.) 
[2]. The antique shop in Maine was owned by E. Prentiss Jones and this wife, Harriet T. Jones. 
[3]. Mrs. Beal purchased several plates and this platter (55.37.2 to 55. 37.10) in August 1955 for an approximate valuation of $200 (see Mrs. Beal's letter to Gordon Washburn, dated August 10, 1955, in donor file.)
[4]. The plate was shipped to Carnegie Institute in August 1955; it was accessioned on December 19, 1955.

Under review by CGK

title: Portrait of a Man
credit_line: Bequest of Howard A. Noble
provenance_text:
Galerie Neumans, Paris, France and Brussels, Belgium until August 1, 1929 [1]; sold to M. Knoedler & Co., London, England, Paris, France, and New York, NY [2]; M. Knoedler & Co., London, England, Paris, France, and New York, NY, August 1, 1929 until September 9, 1932 [3]; sold to Howard A. Noble [1874-1964], Pittsburgh, PA on September 9, 1932 [4]; Howard A. Noble, Pittsburgh, PA, September 9, 1932 until April 30, 1964 [5]; his bequest to Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, May 1964.

Notes: 
[1]. Provenance information before acquisition by Mr. Noble is from the Knoedler Gallery Archive (The Getty Research Institute). Art dealer Gaston Neumans had galleries in Paris and Brussels.
[2]. Sold for £500, as French School, 16th century, attributed to C. de Lyon.
[3]. Knoedler London stock no. A913 
[4]. Mr. Noble purchased the painting in London. The Knoedler New York invoice, dated September 30, 1932, lists a price of $3500 for two paintings purchased in London, this work and 64.11.3.
[5]. In 1944, the painting hung in a bedroom of the Noble residence at 1245 Shady Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA.

title: Portrait of a Young Woman with Wimple and Holding a Pink
credit_line: Bequest of Howard A. Noble
provenance_text:
Marczell von Nemes [1866-1930] Munich, Germany and Budapest, Hungary until May 20, 1927 [1]; sold to M. Knoedler & Co., London, England, Paris, France, and New York, NY [2]; M. Knoedler & Co., London, England, Paris, France, and New York, NY, May 20, 1927 until September 9, 1932 [3]; sold to Howard A. Noble [1874-1964], Pittsburgh, PA on September 9, 1932 [4]; Howard A. Noble, Pittsburgh, PA, September 9, 1932 until April 30, 1964 [5]; his bequest to Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, May 1964.

Notes: 
[1]. Provenance information before acquisition by Mr. Noble is from the Knoedler Gallery Archive (The Getty Research Institute). The Hungarian art collector and dealer Marczell von Nemes was also known as Marczell or Marcel de Nemes. 
[2]. Sold for £800, as "Woman with a Pink" by Master of the Half Lengths. 
[3]. Knoedler London stock no. 8178; Knoedler New York stock no. 16912. During this period, Knoedler changed the attribution of the work, first to Master of the Parrot and then to Flemish School. 
[4]. Mr. Noble purchased the painting in London. The Knoedler New York invoice, dated September 30, 1932, lists a price of $3500 for two paintings purchased in London, this work and 64.11.2.
[5]. In 1944, the painting hung in the parlor of the Noble residence at 1245 Shady Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA.

title: Lidded Crocus jar
credit_line: Bequest of Katherine B. Noble
provenance_text:
Mrs. Howard A. (Katherine Babcock) Noble [c.1880-1954], Pittsburgh, PA by July 1953 until 1954 [1]; life estate to her husband, Howard A. Noble [1874-1964], Pittsburgh PA, 1954 until April 30, 1964 [2]; Katherine B. Noble bequest to Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, May 1964.

Notes:
[1]. The pair of lidded crocus jars, 64.12.1.A-B and 64.12.2.A-B, is included in a codicil of Mrs. Noble's will dated July 28, 1953 (see copy in donor files.)
[2]. The crocus jar and its companion were delivered to the museum in May 1964.

credit_line: Gift of Mrs. James H. Beal
provenance_text:

Notes:
[1]. The antique shop was owned by E. Prentiss Jones and this wife, Harriet T. Jones.
[2]. Mrs. Beal purchased this plate and another one (64.15.2) for $50 (see Mrs. Beal's notes and receipt from The Trade Shop dated July 31, 1964 in donor file.)
[3]. Mrs. Beal delivered the plate to the museum on September 19, 1964; it was accessioned on October 22, 1964.

title: Coffeepot
medium: porcelain with enamel and gilded decoration and silver gilt
credit_line: Ailsa Mellon Bruce Collection
provenance_text:
Ailsa Mellon Bruce

This coffeepot was once part of a service commissioned around 1755 by a member of the English Ramsay family. The coat of arms was granted to John Ramsey of Southwark in London in 1669. The head of the Ramsay family is the Earl of Dalhousie. It is not known which member of the family ordered the Chinese export porcelain service. [see David Sanctuary Howard, "Chinese Armorial Porcelain" p.  484.

title: Portrait of Isabella de' Medici
credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Paul B. Ernst
provenance_text:
Attributed to (circle of) Alessandro Allori [1535-1607], Florence, Italy. Unidentified collection, England, by the mid-19th century [1]. Collis P. Huntington [1821-1900], New York, NY, until August 13, 1900 [2]; bequest to Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, NY, with life interest to his widow, Arabella D. Huntington, [1851-1924], New York, NY, August 13, 1900 until September 16, 1924 [3]; by descent, life interest to Archer Milton Huntington [1870-1955], New York, NY, September 16, 1924 until at least April 30, 1925 [4]; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, NY, by May 1, 1925 [5]; sold at American Art Galleries, New York, NY, November 20, 1925, no. 106 [6]. Arthur E. Braun [1876-1976], Pittsburgh, PA, until December 5, 1976; by descent to his daughter Mrs. Paul B. Ernst (Elizabeth Munhall Braun Ernst) [c. 1906-1987], Pittsburgh, PA, until May 11, 1978; gift to Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, May 1978 [7]. 

Notes:
[1]. In England by the mid-19th century when restored by F. Leedham, who was active in London c.1830-1860. Possibly in the collection of Miss Rogers, London, England, by 1835 (see Waagen II, p. 269: "Agnolo Bronzino. Portrait of Leonora di Toledo, wife of Cosimo I., Grand Duke of Tuscany; half the size of life. An admirable work, distinguished from most of the pictures by this master by the transparency and warmth of the flesh tones.") Miss Rogers (Sarah Rogers [1772-1855]) inherited the collection of her brother Henry Rogers in 1833 or 1834; however, she was also a collector herself. In turn, she left the majority of her collection to another brother the poet Samuel Rogers [1763-1855] at her death in January 1855. After his death in December 1855, his collection was sold at auction in April-May 1856 and included the Bronzino portrait (no. 683.)
[2]. It is not yet clear when and how the painting became part of the Huntington collection but it was in his possession by August 1900.
[3]. Collis P. Huntington, in his will, gave his collection of pictures to the Metropolitan Museum of Art with life interest to Arabella Huntington, his second wife and his adopted son, Archer M. Huntington. Arabella married Henry E. Huntington [1850-1927], who was the nephew of Collis P. Huntington, in July 1913. She is referred to as "Mrs. Henry E. Huntington" in documents after the marriage. 
[4]. Although life interest in this work was transferred to Archer Huntington from Arabella Huntington after her death, he terminated his life interest in 1925 and gave the work, among others in the original bequest, to the Metropolitan Museum. Specifically, this portrait was no. 36 among the paintings delivered to the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the Collis P. Huntington estate on April 30 and May 1, 1925 (see curatorial file.)
[5]. Metropolitan Museum accession number 25.110.131 (written in red paint on stretcher.)
[6]. As by Antonio Allori (Bronzino); sold for $ 430 (see curatorial file for annotated copy of the sales catalogue.)
[7]. Accessioned on May 11, 1978.
